assertions.text: The response describes a forward-looking plan that is explicitly anchored to an upcoming meeting relative to the request time (i.e., T0 is in the future)
The response clearly identifies the target meeting with information such as subject, date/time, and attendees
The response articulates the meeting's objective or desired outcomes to provide context for the workback plan
The response lays out a reverse-chronological workback timeline from the meeting date to the present (or earliest required start date).
The response breaks down the timeline into discrete, manageable tasks or milestones that lead up to the meeting.
The response sequences tasks logically, ensuring that prerequisite activities are scheduled before dependent tasks.
The response includes specific buffers or contingency time to accommodate potential delays or uncertainties.
The response flags any tasks that are on the critical path and explains why.
The response assigns each task to specific owner(s) or, if the owner is unknown, uses an explicit role/placeholder (e.g., 'Presenter', 'Analyst').
The response notes owner capability, availability, or known constraints that could affect task assignments and schedules.
The response identifies key deliverable or artifacts, and when appropriate, specifies expected format, tools, or access location.
The response distinguishes between required deliverables from optional, nice-to-have items
The response includes quality criteria or acceptance standards for key deliverables (e.g., 'final deck approved by LT')
The response provides due dates or date ranges for every task and aligns them logically within the meeting timeline.
The response includes estimated task durations or effort levels to justify the scheduling of start and due dates.
The response explicitly notes tasks that can be completed in parallel versus those that must be done sequentially.
The response provides rationale for compression or acceleration when timelines are tight.
The response identifies upstream dependencies, sequencing constraints, or known blockers for critical tasks, and specifies the required unblock action and responsible owner.
The response specifies how delays in dependencies impact subsequent tasks or the meeting readiness.
The response identifies the potiential risks and outlines mitigation steps with accountable owners
The response lists post-meeting actions (e.g., send notes, upload slides, track action items) with clear owners and deadlines
The response explicitly lists assumptions, open questions, or missing information that may affect the accuracy or completeness of the workback plan
